Abstract

Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has recently emerged as a promising solu-
tion to alleviate Large Language Model (LLM)’s deficiency in lack of knowledge. [S4] Existing RAG datasets, however, do not adequately represent the diverse and dy-
namic nature of real-world Question Answering (QA) tasks. [S5] To bridge this gap, we
introduce the Comprehensive RAG Benchmark (CRAG), a factual question an-
swering benchmark of 4,409 question-answer pairs and mock APIs to simulate web
and Knowledge Graph (KG) search. [S6] CRAG is designed to encapsulate a diverse
array of questions across five domains and eight question categories, reflecting
varied entity popularity from popular to long-tail, and temporal dynamisms ranging
from years to seconds. [S7] Our evaluation of this benchmark highlights the gap to
fully trustworthy QA. [S8] Whereas most advanced LLMs achieve ď 34% accuracy
on CRAG, adding RAG in a straightforward manner improves the accuracy only
to 44%. [S9] State-of-the-art industry RAG solutions only answer 63% of questions
without any hallucination. [S10] CRAG also reveals much lower accuracy in answer-
ing questions regarding facts with higher dynamism, lower popularity, or higher
complexity, suggesting future research directions. [S11] The CRAG benchmark laid the
groundwork for a KDD Cup 2024 challenge and attracted thousands of participants
and submissions. [S12] We commit to maintaining CRAG to serve research communities
in advancing RAG solutions and general QA solutions. [S13] CRAG is available at
https://github.com/facebookresearch/CRAG/. [S14] 1

Introduction

Large Language Models (LLMs) have transformed the landscape of Natural Language Processing
(NLP) tasks, especially in Question Answering (QA) [20, 22, 38, 39]. [S15] Despite the advancements,
the issue of hallucination persists as a significant challenge; LLMs may generate answers that lack
factual accuracy or grounding [14,27,30,32]. [S16] Studies have shown that GPT-4’s accuracy in answering
questions referring to slow-changing or fast-changing facts is below 15% [36]; even for stable (never-
changing) facts, GPT-4’s accuracy in answering questions referring to torso-to-tail (less popular)
entities is below 35% [29]. [S17] Overcoming hallucinations thus becomes a priority in building reliable
QA systems [13, 14]. [S18] Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) [6, 8, 12, 19] has recently emerged as a promising solution to
alleviate LLM’s deficiency in lack of knowledge and attracted a lot of attention from both academia
research and industry. [S19] Given a question, a RAG system searches external sources to retrieve relevant
information and then provides grounded answers [7, 12, 19] (see Figure 1 for an illustration). [S20] Despite

[S26] A comprehensive benchmark is currently missing to advance continued research efforts in this field. [S27] Our goal is to build a benchmark that can provide a holistic view of the important capabilities and
fast but reliable evaluation for RAG to propel the area forward. [S28] What is a good benchmark for QA
over LLMs? [S29] We consider five critical features. [S30] 1. [S31] Realism: First and foremost, a good benchmark shall best reflect real use cases. [S32] In other
words, a solution that achieves high metrics in the benchmark shall also perform very well in
real scenarios. [S33] For example, the questions in a RAG benchmark shall be similar to questions
people ask in real-world QA scenarios. [S34] 2. [S35] Richness: The benchmark shall contain a diverse set of instance types, covering both
common use cases and some complex and advanced use cases, to represent real-world
challenges and reveal possible limitations of existing solutions. [S36] 3. [S37] Insightfulness: The benchmark shall allow for an easy understanding of performance on
different slices of the data, reflecting the capability of the solution in addressing different
types of challenges. [S38] 4. [S39] Reliability: The benchmark shall allow reliable assessment of metrics: the ground truths
shall be accurate; the metrics shall well capture the performance of the model; the evaluation
shall be easy and reliable, and the computed metrics shall hold statistical significance. [S40] 5. [S41] Longevity: Finally, to enable research and experimental comparison in a long term, the
scenarios and the data in the benchmark shall not quickly expire and ideally shall be refreshed
and improved over time. [S42] We strive to create a benchmark that have all of the aforementioned features, and we call it CRAG –
Comprehensive benchmark for RAG. [S43] Our work makes three contributions.

TriviaQA [16], MS MARCO [4], and QALD-10 [35] have advanced QA in the past decade but
consider only web retrieved or KG retrieved contents, and do not adequately represent the diverse

3.1 Question answering pairs

CRAG covers five domains: Finance, Sports, Music, Movie, and Open domain, and eight types of
questions, all in English. [S2] The question types are listed in Table 2. [S3] We constructed the question-answer
pairs both from underlying KGs and web contents. [S4] QA pairs constructed from KGs. [S5] We constructed QA pairs from KGs by collecting a set of entities
based on publicly available data and then creating 600+ question templates based on selected entity
types and relations. [S6] Next, we sampled entities with different popularities (head, torso and tail)
following [29] from the KGs to fill in the templates and generate the full question and answer. [S7] QA pairs constructed from web contents. [S8] We asked annotators to write down possible questions
that users may ask (e.g., “most popular action movies in 2023”) and created QA pairs from the
corresponding web search results. [S9] Using the above methods, we collected 2,425 Web Questions and 1,984 KG Questions, with 661, 658,
and 665 KG Questions containing head, torso, and tail entities respectively. [S10] Tables 3 and 4 summarize
the distribution of the questions across different dimensions. [S11] The size of each dimension slice (e.g.,
fast-changing facts) allows us to get metrics with ă 5% margin-of-error (with 95% confidence level)
for most of the cases. [S12] The dynamism distribution roughly reflects the nature of the domain (e.g.,
much more real-time questions for Finance than for other domains). [S13] See Appendix A.1.2 for the
definition of the dynamism categories. [S14] 3.2 Contents for retrieval

We included two types of contents for retrieval to simulate the practical scenario for RAG: web search
and KG search. [S15] Web search results. [S16] For each question, we used the question text as the search query and stored up
to 50 HTML pages from the Brave search API [5]. [S17] See Table 8 in Appendix A.1.5 for an example. [S18] We estimated the web search recall with a heuristic-based method: first check whether the ground
truth answer URL was found among the pages; if not, decide whether the fact in the ground truths is
contained in the page snippet or content with an LLM. [S19] In particular, we pass the question, ground
truth, and the pages to Llama 3 70B Instruct and ask it to judge if the context is sufficient to answer
the question. [S20] 5

truth facts. [S21] The curve shows that the retrieval recall grows sharply at the beginning and flattens out
later on. [S22] Figure 2 shows the estimated web search recall curve for all CRAG questions, with an overall recall
of 85% when using all 50 pages. [S23] It reflects multiple advantages of the benchmark by design. [S24] First,

Similar to previous work [37], we employ both human evaluation (human-eval) and model-based
automatic evaluation (auto-eval). [S11] In the former, we use manual grading to judge perfect, acceptable,
missing, and incorrect for each answer. [S12] In the latter, we merge perfect and acceptable, call it accurate,
and use a three-way scoring system with 1, ´1, 0 for accurate, incorrect, and missing answers. [S13] We design a two-step method for automatic evaluation: if the answer matches the ground truth exactly,
it is considered accurate; otherwise, we use LLMs to determine whether the response is accurate,
incorrect, or missing. [S14] To avoid the self-preference problem [25], we use two LLM evaluators:
ChatGPT (gpt-3.5-turbo-0125) [24] and Llama 3 (llama-3-70B-instruct) [2] and report the
average accurate, hallucination, missing rates, and truthfulness scores from the two models for each
RAG system. [S15] Our offline experiment shows that this two-step method yields an average F1 score of
94.7% for ChatGPT and 98.9% for Llama 3 compared to human-eval. [S16] See Appendix A.2.2 for more
details. [S17] Test data split. [S18] We split the data randomly into validation (30%), public test (30%), and private
(40%), and released the validation and public test sets (Appendix A.2.3). [S19] Participants of the KDD
Cup challenge can use the validation and public test sets to develop and test their models, and the
submitted solutions were evaluated on the private test set. [S20] Future offline users of CRAG can use
the validation set for development, fine-tuning, and validation, and the public test set for testing and
result reporting. [S21] 5 Benchmarking

that CRAG has a reasonable level of difficulty and can help draw insights and show directions in
developing RAG techniques. [S22] 5.1 Straightforward RAG solutions

A.1 Dataset

A.1.1 Constructing QA pairs from KGs

We first collected a set of entities based on publicly available data. [S129] Then we created question-answer
pairs in three steps for Simple static and dynamic questions. [S130] Step 1. [S131] For each domain, we first selected an entity type and a meaningful relation pe, rq and created
a question template. [S132] For example, for (music artist, first album), we create a template “what is the
first album of [music artist]?”. [S133] Step 2. [S134] We then sampled entities from the KGs to fill in the templates and generate the full question. [S135] We adopted the method described in [29] and sampled entities of top, middle, and bottom popularity. [S136] We defined popularity based on heuristics for each entity type and created an equal number of
questions for each bucket. [S137] Step 3. [S138] Last, we took the associated attribute values as the answer to the question to create question-
answer pairs. [S139] We created the Comparison, Aggregation, Set, Post-processing, and False-premise questions in a
similar way but 1) made sure the template allows for crisp and deterministic answers and 2) sampled
the subject entities that fit the question. [S140] We used heuristics to select entity types for these question
categories. [S141] Finally, we created multi-hop questions in three steps, similar to those described in [31]. [S142] We first
sampled an entity e1 from the KG and selected two relation triplets following a two-hop path:
pe1, r1, e2q and pe1, r2, e3q. [S143] We then created a question template describing the path. [S144] For example,
for path (company1, is_parent, company2) followed by (company1, ceo, person), we created the
template "who is the CEO of the parent company of [company2]?". [S145] The answer to the new question
will be e3 in the second triplet. [S146] A.1.2 Definition of dynamism categories

Step 1. [S152] Ask annotators to write down a list of questions that could possibly be answered by web
search based on a general guideline (e.g., “what is the most popular action movie in 2023?”). [S153] Step 2. [S154] Generate the web search results to answer the question. [S155] Step 3. [S156] Finally, annotators reviewed the web search results to determine the ground truth answers to
the questions: 1) If the search results successfully provided the necessary information, annotators

for the Fast-changing and Real-time questions. [S158] 2) Otherwise, annotators conducted further web
searches to document the correct answers. [S159] 13

The KDD Cup 2024 Meta CRAG challenge has two stages. [S22] Stage 1 is designed for the participants to
